Wow, I can't  believe it.  The scan you put in my folder.  The one top left=
 is identical to mine.  Same crickets. And the signature is identical to th=
e one someone posted as a mino.  So now I know about the tsuba.  So what ab=
out the sword?  Is the maker of the sword and the tsuba generally completel=
y different people?  schools?  are they totally disassociated or might ther=
e be some swordsmiths that tended to use tsubas from this particular school=
?
   
  Becky

Curran Campbell <neobliviscar@...> wrote:
          Be=
cky,

I posted a scan in your folder. It should answer most
of your questio=
n. According to Gary Murtha's Sword
Fittings book pg 44, it is probably a t=
suba by Kyoto
Kiyonori or one of his students.

I've seen this tsuba a few =
times over the years. If
you (carefully) remove the pin holding on the tsuk=
a
and look at the face of the tsuba that was under the
tsuka, you will (may=
be 50/50 %) see a gold 'KAO' mark
like that on the tsuba images uploaded to=
 your folder.
The Kao will probably allow us to attribute it to a
specific =
person, althought the KAO shown by Murtha and
that recorded by Haynes are s=
omewhat different for
these guys. Still, we should have a good idea.

Accor=
ding to Murtha, Kiyonori was "A Kyoto artist.
Signed with gold inlaid kao. =
His favorite design being
crickets in grass. One of his students was Atsuiy=
e who
changed his name to Noriiye."

They are nice tsubas. One of the fello=
w listmembers
had one a few years back. If he sold it, he could
probably te=
ll you the value best.
I did not look closely, but do the fuchi-kashira
mat=
ch the tsuba in design? That would be nice.

Curran
